statement.tex: %text What is the coefficient of $x^2$ in the expansion of \[ \left(\frac{2}{3}x-\frac{3}{2x}\right)^6 \]? %

\\ %text If \[ \left(\frac{2}{3}x-\frac{3}{2x}\right)^6 = \overbrace{\underbrace{T_1 + T_2 + \cdots + T_N}_{\text{N terms}}}^{\longrightarrow\text{ increasing powers of x}}\] then \underline\text{are the following true}? %
\\ %text Given \[ T_m = ^6C_{m-1}\left(\frac{2x}{3}\right)^{m-1}\], we will get a $\dfrac{1}{x^2}$ term when the following is true. \textbf{Right or wrong?} %
\\ %text Given that $m=3$, the coefficient of the required term will be the following. \textbf{Right or wrong?} %

reason.tex:
%text $(a+b)^n$ has $(n+1) terms.
And therefore,, \[ \left(\frac{2}{3}x-\frac{3}{2x}\right)^6\] will have $N=6+1=7$ terms.
Also, \underline\text{if we expand in increasing} powers of $x$, then the \underline\text{powers of \[\left(\frac{2x}{3}\right)\]} should increase as we go from $T_1\longrightarrow T_7$.
Hence, the m-th term would be
% \begin{align} T_m &= ^6C_{m-1}\left(\frac{2x}{3}\right)^{m-1} \cdot \left(-\frac{3}{2x}\right)^{6-(m-1)} \\ &=^6C_{m-1}\left(\frac{2x}{3}\right)^{m-1}\cdot (-1)^{7-m} \cdot \left(\frac{3}{2x}\right)^{7-m} \\ & (1\leq m\leq 7) \end{align} %text
\textbf{Note that we could have expanded in} \textbf{decreasing powers of x too.}
The final answer would not change. After all, it is the same binomial expansion. %
